job_title: Senior Executive Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The paycheck is a delusion of doing well. Staff exist to serve their masters' (faculty) every beck and call, but not to live a full life outside the ivory tower plantation.
cons: The reality of life within the "academy" does not match the rhetoric used for PR. It is a toxic culture from top down. Rules of civility do not apply to faculty and especially not to assistant deans who are married to deans of other departments. Bullying is rampant and is quickly learned as the only way of getting ahead, so staff will destroy each other to survive by amusing their "masters" with their mimicry. The bullying is felt in merciless rants and destructive verbal assaults that are used to ruthlessly destroy innocent staff in the most extreme imbalance of power, just because they can. We can smell the "bitterness" on an assistant dean's breath a mile away. Yet, he still gets to keep a job, making everyone below him miserable for decades. Staff have no human rights as deans and faculty can make false allegations without facts, without accountability, but with impunity. HR is not there to help the common person. Don't even think about going through the useless channels to report abuse. It will be used to get rid of the witnesses, not the problem.

review_title: Being a Research Assistant at the University of Michigan.
job_title: Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Access to valuable research resources: As a research assistant, you will have access to a wide range of resources such as databases, research materials, and other academic tools. Experience and skill development: This role will provide you with valuable experience and the opportunity to develop your research and analytical skills. Networking opportunities: Working as a research assistant can provide you with opportunities to meet and work with other academics, researchers, and professionals in your field of study. Potential for academic credit: In some cases, you may be able to receive academic credit for your work as a research assistant.
cons: Time commitment: Being a research assistant can be a time-consuming role, especially if you have other academic commitments such as classes and coursework. Limited autonomy: As a research assistant, you will likely be working under the guidance and direction of a supervisor, which can limit your autonomy and independence. Pay may be low or non-existent: Many research assistant positions do not offer a high level of pay, and some may not offer any payment at all. Work may not align with personal interests: Depending on the project or research focus, you may find that the work you are doing as a research assistant does not align with your personal academic interests or goals.

Some employees are very complacent and nearly impossible to fire, especially the ones with many years of experience; however, a large percentage of employees are also clearly overqualified and underpaid for their roles. This is the most educated city in the US and so well-paying job options are limited, especially for "trailing spouses" of doctors or academics; many, myself included, take the hit because we like the area and working in higher education, or have other factors like kids tying us to the area. job_title: Research Administrator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Decently competitive pay (depending on field — I worked in research Admin. in LSA but some other colleges/schools have better pay)

Excellent benefits (health insurance, 2:1 403(b)., tuition assistance, vacation and sick time, etc.) !!! 

Very supportive learning and working environment. Professional and personal growth are emphasized

Flexible work environment (WFH, Flex Time, etc)

Once you’re in the UM system, it’s pretty easy to stay in the system for your entire career and move around to different fields, schools, roles, etc.
cons:
Bureaucratic and slow-moving, even with good intentions at the core (like any large academic institution)

Must advocate for yourself for promotions (pros and cons to this, but it actually makes it more challenging to get promoted once you’ve been here for a few years) — many people move around to different schools/colleges to make progressive escalations in their career and/or to learn new roles/fields

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Of course all of this depends on your advisor but for me:
- Flexibility and support for working on personal projects alongside necessary projects
- Really friendly, smart, collaborative coworkers
- The research is typically pretty meaningful and practical
- Very enjoyable working experience
cons:
- Human resources is kind of a mess. I was continuously misinformed about COBRA health insurance benefits over the phone and met an unreasonable amount of resistance to getting anything in writing.
- Was short-changed a month and a half of salary through some COVID-related loopholes during the transition from PhD student to Postdoc, and was given no warning that I would not be paid. These were weeks I was actively working for U of M and did not get paid.
- Extremely slow review times on paper revisions once I was remote and not meeting regularly with my advisor. I should have been given consent to submit our collaborative papers myself or should have been given more prompt feedback, but instead I was held in limbo for months.

cons: Though Ann Arbor is an awesome place to study and live, it is not that great for finding a job as compared to universities located in big cities. job_title: Researcher%2C PhD Candidate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Access to cutting edge technology and resources .

There are numerous leading experts across many different fields.

For biomedical research, affiliation with the hospital lowers the barrier to study human tissues.

Through the PIBS program you are guaranteed funding for your first year. Once you join a lab, the PI becomes responsible for you. As part of your training you will almost certainly be pushed and encouraged to apply for grants, fellowships, and other independent funding.

Really excellent health insurance options - you can add a significant other and other dependents to be covered as well.
cons:
Laboratory research space is spread out across many corners of campus, departments can feel siloed or even split up due to being the medical school campus or at the NCRC.

The university treats grad students like students or like employees whenever it is convenient for them.

The channels for reporting work place harassment or mistreatment by your PI/advisor are vaguely defined and enforced and often operate at the expense of student safety and to protect a faculty member.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Dearborn, MI
pros:
- Vacation and sick time was very generous.
- Depending on your role, work/life balance can be good.
cons:
No advancement or growth opportunities for 90% of the people that work there unless someone retires or dies. A lot of the people who somehow ended up in management will stay there forever because they are the only ones who keep getting promoted (eg, from manager to senior manager to director to executive director, even though their job duties remain mostly the same) and their pay continues to go up even though they are resistant to change and insist on doing things the way they’ve always been done to the detriment of the students. Employees not in management roles rarely, if ever, get promoted or get pay increases beyond cost of living (honestly, you’re lucky if you even get that). You can get a perfect performance review for years, be told that your contributions are valuable, etc. but the university will claim poverty and not reward your contributions with more than a pat on the back, despite increasing tuition costs and record enrollment. They will, however, increase your workload or level of responsibility.

Service unit employees are generally treated poorly by the colleges and enrollment management. Their ideas are not valued and they are not treated as strategic partners but rather as people who were hired to do whatever the deans and senior leadership of other departments tell them to do. There is also so much organizational drama and office politics slow everything down and make day-to-day work life miserable.

I did genuinely like some of the people I worked with but the feeling of “we’re a big happy family” is hard to swallow when you reflect on the way you were treated once you go to an organization where you actually are valued. I realized that I had experienced employer Stockholm syndrome, as I often defended the poor treatment and pay by buying into and repeating the lies told by management.

I also heard from several students and prospectives that their experiences dealing with certain departments on campus were frustrating and discouraging. Disorganized departments with poor customer service are turning prospectives away and thus turning away tuition dollars. But when you try to tell anyone in a leadership position about this, they don’t listen or are too ineffective to fix the issue.
